joeyr 0.3.5
  • Reference

Filter vowel measurements.

joey_filter.Rd

Description goes here.

joey_filter(
  df,
  F1 = "F1",
  F2 = "F2",
  vowel = "vowel",
  method = "pca",
  filter = "cooksd",
  cutoff = 0,
  boost = 3,
  keep = FALSE
)

Arguments

df

A grouped dataframe including F1, F2, and vowel columns.
F1

A quoted string of the column name containing F1 measurements. By default, a column named "F1" is used.
F2

A quoted string of the column name containing F2 measurements. By default, a column named "F2" is used.
vowel

A quoted string of the column name containing the "vowel" column. This would be the column that identifies what vowel quality the observations in the row belong to. By default, a column named "vowel" is used.
method

A string. By default, "pca" is used, which will perform a principal components analysis on the data and do a regression analysis on the first two principal components. This is prefered since it takes into account the correlation in the data.

As an alternative, "f1f2" can be used instead (technically any string other than "pca"), which does a regression on the raw formant measurements. This is akin to filtering by normalized F1 and F2 (perhaps by removing anything more than 3 standard deviations from the mean), but it finds a new mean and standard deviation after removing each point.
filter

A string. By default, the method is "cooksd", meaning that outliers are detected using Cook's D. Any observation with a Cook's D greater than the "cutoff" is considered an outlier. If any other string is used, such as \"z-score\" than outliers are detected based on a z-score. The data is normalized and any observation further than *n* standard deviations from the mean is considered an outlier. The cutoff, in standard deviation units, is specified in the "cutoff" parameter.
cutoff

A number. When using Cook's D as the "filter", any observation with a Cook's D higher than this value is considered an outlier. By default, the rule of thumb for Cook's D is used: $$4/(n - k - 1)$$ where n is the number of observations, and k is the number of variables, which in this case, is 2 (PC1 and PC2 or F1 and F2).

Usually, the number of observations will be different for each vowel within the same speaker, so this value will be different from vowel to vowel. If, however, a specific cutoff value is wanted that should be used for all vowels regardless of how many observations there are or their distribution, it can be specified here.

When using z-score as the "filter", the default is that any observations further than 2 standard deviations from the mean are considered outliers. This can changed by specifying a number here.
boost

A number. When using "Cook's D" as the "method", the rule of thumb cutoff value is often too strong and removes too many observations. To make the filter weaker, the cutoff value is multiplied by the "boost" value. By default, it is set to "3". To apply no filter and to use the exact cutoff value, set this value to "1". If the "cutoff" value is specified or if z-score is used as the filter, this parameter is quiety ignored.
keep

Logical. By default, outliers are removed from the data frame. However, if you would like to keep them (for examination), set this argument to "TRUE". This will create a new TRUE/FALSE column called "is_outlier" that will identify whether that particular observation was determined to be an outlier.

Value

A dataframe. Outliers are removed if "keep = FALSE" so there will be fewer rows. If "keep = TRUE", a new variable, "is_outlier" will be tagged on the end.

Examples

laterals <- read.csv("joey.csv") %>%
    group_by(vowel)
#> Warning: cannot open file 'joey.csv': No such file or directory
#> Error in file(file, "rt"): cannot open the connection

# Detect outliers using Cook's D based on a PCA regression.
joey_filter(laterals)
#> Error in joey_filter(laterals): could not find function "joey_filter"
# a stronger filter
joey_filter(laterals, boost = 2)
#> Error in joey_filter(laterals, boost = 2): could not find function "joey_filter"
# with blanket cutoff score
joey_filter(laterals, cutoff = 0.1)
#> Error in joey_filter(laterals, cutoff = 0.1): could not find function "joey_filter"

# Detect outliers using Cook's D based on F1 and F2 values.
joey_filter(laterals, method = "f1f2")
#> Error in joey_filter(laterals, method = "f1f2"): could not find function "joey_filter"

# Detect outliers using z-score based on PCA regression.
joey_filter(laterals, filter = "z-score")
#> Error in joey_filter(laterals, filter = "z-score"): could not find function "joey_filter"

# Detect outliers using z-score based on F1 and F2 values.
joey_filter(laterals, method = "f1f2", filter = "z-score")
#> Error in joey_filter(laterals, method = "f1f2", filter = "z-score"): could not find function "joey_filter"
# Based z > 2.5 instead of z > 2.
joey_filter(laterals, method = "f1f2", filter = "z-score", cutoff = 2.5)
#> Error in joey_filter(laterals, method = "f1f2", filter = "z-score", cutoff = 2.5): could not find function "joey_filter"

# Specify column names.
joey_filter(laterals, F1 = "F1.50.", F2 = "F2.50.", vowel = "phoneme")
#> Error in joey_filter(laterals, F1 = "F1.50.", F2 = "F2.50.", vowel = "phoneme"): could not find function "joey_filter"

# Keep the outliers.
joey_filter(laterals, keep = TRUE)
#> Error in joey_filter(laterals, keep = TRUE): could not find function "joey_filter"
